articles.headline: Howard Schultz to Step Down as Starbucks Executive Chairman
articles.snippet: Mr. Schultz’s decision to retire from Starbucks, a plan he says he privately outlined to the board a year ago, could stoke speculation that he is considering a move into politics.
articles.abstract: Mr. Schultz’s decision to retire from Starbucks, a plan he says he privately outlined to the board a year ago, could stoke speculation that he is considering a move into politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Howard Schultz, the outspoken executive chairman of Starbucks, will leave the company at the end of the month, bringing to an end the tenure of a socially conscious entrepreneur who turned a local Seattle coffee chain into a global giant with more than 28,000 stores in 77 countries.

articles.headline: Apple Shuns the Tech Industry’s Apology Tour
articles.snippet: At the Apple developers’ conference, it was striking how company executives danced around the tech backlash.
articles.abstract: At the Apple developers’ conference, it was striking how company executives danced around the tech backlash.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif. — Sorry, Apple’s not sorry.

articles.headline: Schultz 2020? Other C.E.O.s Will Be Watching Closely
articles.snippet: Several prominent chief executives are considering running for president. But “the history of business leaders in the White House has not been good.”
articles.abstract: Several prominent chief executives are considering running for president. But “the history of business leaders in the White House has not been good.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Since Donald Trump was unexpectedly elected president on Nov. 8, 2016, speculation has swirled about whether another well-known business leader might make a bid for the White House in 2020.

articles.headline: Trump and His Lawyers Embrace a Vision of Vast Executive Power
articles.snippet: The president and his personal legal advisers have argued to the special counsel that his authority places him above the reach of obstruction statutes.
articles.abstract: The president and his personal legal advisers have argued to the special counsel that his authority places him above the reach of obstruction statutes.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump, ramping up his assertions of extraordinary powers, declared in a tweet on Monday that he had “the absolute right” to pardon himself for any crime.

articles.headline: Mueller Accuses Paul Manafort of Attempted Witness Tampering
articles.snippet: Prosecutors say President Trump’s former campaign chairman tried to contact witnesses in the case against him. They want his bail revoked or revised.
articles.abstract: Prosecutors say President Trump’s former campaign chairman tried to contact witnesses in the case against him. They want his bail revoked or revised.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal prosecutors on Monday accused President Trump’s former campaign chairman, Paul Manafort, of attempting to tamper with witnesses in his federal tax and money laundering case.

articles.headline: A Trump-Kim Deal Could Send China’s Trade With North Korea Soaring
articles.snippet: A shadowy gray market of “shuttle traders” and money couriers already exists, and economic ties could quickly take off if sanctions are lifted.
articles.abstract: A shadowy gray market of “shuttle traders” and money couriers already exists, and economic ties could quickly take off if sanctions are lifted.
articles.lead_paragraph: HUNCHUN, China — In the Chinese border town of Hunchun, garment factories gladly employ squads of North Koreans, who are valued as skilled and dutiful workers. Live crab from the North wriggle in huge tanks in the fish market. Informal bankers promise to deliver the equivalent of thousands of dollars in Chinese currency to North Koreans across the border in a matter of hours.

articles.headline: U.K. Clears Way for Bidding War Between Comcast and Disney Over Sky
articles.snippet: A decision by Britain’s culture secretary sets up a new phase in a battle between two media giants, as the industry rushes to consolidate.
articles.abstract: A decision by Britain’s culture secretary sets up a new phase in a battle between two media giants, as the industry rushes to consolidate.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Comcast wants to upend the Walt Disney Company’s empire-building plans, and a jewel of Europe’s media industry could give it an opening.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Mexico, Hitting Back, Imposes Tariffs on $3 Billion Worth of U.S. Goods
articles.snippet: The move came as the administration suggested it wants to split the Nafta talks and negotiate separate agreements with Mexico and Canada.
articles.abstract: The move came as the administration suggested it wants to split the Nafta talks and negotiate separate agreements with Mexico and Canada.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Mexico hit back at the United States on Tuesday, imposing tariffs on around $3 billion worth of American pork, steel, cheese and other goods in response to the Trump administration’s steel and aluminum levies, further straining relations between the two countries as they struggle to rewrite the North American Free Trade Agreement.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson and Jim Tankersley
